Sourcing Table.Sourced Statement: Sam Altman called an OpenAI board member’s research paper a danger to the company weeks before he was ousted as its chief executive.
Sourcing Table.Source Justification: Sam Altman, the chief executive

Sourcing Table.Sourced Statement: Another member, Ilya Sutskever, thought Mr. Altman was not always being honest when talking with the board.
Sourcing Table.Source Justification: Another member, Ilya Sutskever

Sourcing Table.Sourced Statement: The news that he was being pushed out came in a videoconference on Friday afternoon, when Mr. Sutskever, who had worked closely with Mr. Altman at OpenAI for eight years, read him a statement.
Sourcing Table.Source Justification: Mr. Sutskever, who had worked closely with Mr. Altman at OpenAI for eight years

Sourcing Table.Sourced Statement: Those tensions seemingly came to an end late Tuesday when Mr. Altman was reinstated as chief executive. Mr. Sutskever and others critical of Mr. Altman were jettisoned from the board, whose members now include Bret Taylor, an early Facebook officer and former co-chief executive of Salesforce, and Larry Summers, the former Treasury Department secretary. The only holdover is Adam D’Angelo, chief executive of the question-and-answer site, Quora.
Sourcing Table.Source Justification: Mr. Altman was reinstated as chief executive

Sourcing Table.Sourced Statement: Among the tensions leading up to Mr. Altman’s ouster and quick return involved his conflict with Helen Toner, a board member and a director of strategy at Georgetown University’s Center for Security and Emerging Technology.
Sourcing Table.Title of Source: board member and a director of strategy at Georgetown University’s Center for Security and Emerging Technology
Sourcing Table.Source Justification: Helen Toner, a board member and a director of strategy at Georgetown University’s Center for Security and Emerging Technology

Sourcing Table.Sourced Statement: Mr. Altman complained that the research paper seemed to criticize OpenAI’s efforts to keep its A.I. technologies safe while praising the approach taken by Anthropic, a company that has become OpenAI’s biggest rival, according to an email that Mr. Altman wrote to colleagues and that was viewed by The New York Times.
Sourcing Table.Source Justification: Mr. Altman, the chief executive

Sourcing Table.Sourced Statement: In the email, Mr. Altman said that he had reprimanded Ms. Toner for the paper and that it was dangerous to the company, particularly at a time, he added, when the Federal Trade Commission was investigating OpenAI over the data used to build its technology.
Sourcing Table.Source Justification: Mr. Altman, the chief executive

Sourcing Table.Sourced Statement: Ms. Toner defended it as an academic paper that analyzed the challenges that the public faces when trying to understand the intentions of the countries and companies developing A.I.
Sourcing Table.Title of Source: board member and a director of strategy at Georgetown University’s Center for Security and Emerging Technology
Sourcing Table.Source Justification: Helen Toner, a board member and a director of strategy at Georgetown University’s Center for Security and Emerging Technology

Sourcing Table.Sourced Statement: “I did not feel we’re on the same page on the damage of all this,” he wrote in the email. “Any amount of criticism from a board member carries a lot of weight.”
Sourcing Table.Source Justification: Mr. Altman, the chief executive

Sourcing Table.Sourced Statement: Senior OpenAI leaders, including Mr. Sutskever, who is deeply concerned that A.I. could one day destroy humanity, later discussed whether Ms. Toner should be removed, a person involved in the conversations said.
Sourcing Table.Source Justification: Senior OpenAI leaders, including Mr. Sutskever

Sourcing Table.Sourced Statement: But shortly after those discussions, Mr. Sutskever did the unexpected: He sided with board members to oust Mr. Altman, according to two people familiar with the board’s deliberations.
Sourcing Table.Source Justification: Mr. Sutskever, a board member

Sourcing Table.Sourced Statement: The statement he read to Mr. Altman said that Mr. Altman was being fired because he wasn’t “consistently candid in his communications with the board.”
Sourcing Table.Source Justification: Mr. Sutskever, a board member

Sourcing Table.Sourced Statement: “After a series of reasonably amicable negotiations, the co-founders of Anthropic were able to negotiate their exit on mutually agreeable terms,” an Anthropic spokeswoman, Sally Aldous, said.
Sourcing Table.Source Justification: Sally Aldous, Anthropic spokeswoman

Sourcing Table.Sourced Statement: In a second statement, Anthropic added that there was “no attempt to ‘oust’ Sam Altman at the time the founders of Anthropic left OpenAI.”
Sourcing Table.Source Justification: Anthropic, a company that has become OpenAI’s biggest rival

Sourcing Table.Sourced Statement: After vetting four candidates for one position, the remaining directors couldn’t agree on who should fill it, said the two people familiar with the board’s deliberations.
Sourcing Table.Source Justification: two people familiar with the board’s deliberations

Sourcing Table.Sourced Statement: Hours after Mr. Altman was ousted, OpenAI executives confronted the remaining board members during a video call, according to three people who were on the call.
Sourcing Table.Source Justification: three people who were on the call

Sourcing Table.Sourced Statement: During the call, Jason Kwon, OpenAI’s chief strategy officer, said the board was endangering the future of the company by pushing out Mr. Altman. This, he said, violated the members’ responsibilities.
Sourcing Table.Source Justification: Jason Kwon, OpenAI’s chief strategy officer

Sourcing Table.Sourced Statement: Ms. Toner disagreed. The board’s mission was to ensure that the company creates artificial intelligence that “benefits all of humanity,” and if the company was destroyed, she said, that could be consistent with its mission. In the board’s view, OpenAI would be stronger without Mr. Altman.
Sourcing Table.Title of Source: board member and a director of strategy at Georgetown University’s Center for Security and Emerging Technology
Sourcing Table.Source Justification: Helen Toner, a board member and a director of strategy at Georgetown University’s Center for Security and Emerging Technology

Sourcing Table.Sourced Statement: On Sunday, Mr. Sutskever was urged at OpenAI’s office to reverse course by Mr. Brockman’s wife, Anna, according to two people familiar with the exchange.
Sourcing Table.Source Justification: two people familiar with the exchange

Sourcing Table.Sourced Statement: Hours later, he signed a letter with other employees that demanded the independent directors resign.
Sourcing Table.Source Justification: other employees

Sourcing Table.Sourced Statement: The confrontation between Mr. Sutskever and Ms. Brockman was reported earlier by The Wall Street Journal.
Sourcing Table.Source Justification: The Wall Street Journal, a news organization

Sourcing Table.Sourced Statement: At 5:15 a.m. on Monday, he posted on X, formerly Twitter, that “I deeply regret my participation in the board’s actions.”
Sourcing Table.Source Justification: Ilya Sutskever, board member
